awd_titl_txt: Nuclear, Particle, and Weak Interaction Physics of the Big Bang and Stellar Collapse
awd_abstract_narration:
The research supported in this Project will provide insights into how atomic nuclei and radiation behave in extreme conditions of temperature and density. In turn, this research will seek to leverage these insights to provide important clues about the nature of elementary particles, the mysterious neutrinos in particular, and about how the elements are synthesized in nature, e.g., in the fiery interiors of stars. These are grand science questions and a significant part of the world's physics and astronomy endeavor is directed toward answering them. For example, recent experiments have revealed some of the properties of the ghost-like neutrinos, and planned experiments seek to uncover more. An objective of this Project will be to better understand the implications of these properties for the grand questions described above. This will require honing humanity's fundamental theory of nature, i.e., Quantum Mechanics, into a tool capable of modeling the behavior of neutrinos in the extreme environments provided by the cosmos. Another key product of this Project will be the training of young nuclear physicists, at both the graduate and undergraduate levels. 

The research supported in this Project will be directed toward probing the fundamental physics of neutrinos and nuclei by exploiting the intersection of exciting new developments in nuclear physics and neutrino physics on the one hand, with rapidly advancing probes of astrophysical environments on the other. A key issue in this enterprise will be studying how neutrinos interact in dense matter and how these interactions may cause neutrinos to change their flavors (e.g., electron type neutrinos changing to tau type and vice versa) and/or their spins (e.g., left-handed to right-handed, and vice versa - if neutrinos are Majorana in character this is tantamount to changing neutrinos to antineutrinos). This is a fiercely nonlinear problem because neutrino flavor/spin determines how neutrinos interact, and how they interact determines how flavors/spin change. To these ends, the P.I. and his graduate and undergraduate students will work toward: (1) Understanding and modeling the quantum kinetic equations which govern neutrino flavor and spin evolution in a general medium; (2) Constructing large-scale numerical simulations of neutrino flavor/spin evolution in various supernova, stellar collapse, and compact object merger environments and assessing the feedback of this neutrino flavor physics on the prospects for the synthesis of nuclei in these sites; (3) Understanding nuclear structure, neutrino-nucleus interactions, nuclear partition functions, and weak strength distributions in high temperature environments.

por.por_cntn:
Science, physics, is about discovering and understanding how the world works, both on the small scale of atoms and atomic nuclei and on the largest scales of the universe. The research supported by this NSF Award (i.e., supported by the taxpayers of the United States) revealed connections between the largest scales and the smallest, leveraging new insights into both. Along the way, these investigations advanced techniques for using humanity's fundamental theory of how nature works, quantum mechanics, and resulted in the formation and training of young nuclear physicists.

Much remains mysterious about the behavior and properties of the most basic constituents of matter, particualry about elementary particles and their interactions with matter. The ghost-like neutrinos, arguably the most mysterious of these, present special challenges for study via conventional techniques, for example, in accelerator- and nuclear reactor-based experiments. This is because of the very feeble nature of the interaction of these particles with ordinary matter. Nevertheless, these experiments have revealed intriguing behaviors of these particles. These behaviours suggest that there is much we do not understand about these particles, but they also suggest ways in which the neutrinos could play an outsized role in some of the most dramatic events in the cosmos.

We are in the midst of a revolution in our ability to study these dramatic events in the cosmos. This is occaisioned by the great observatories, for example those measuring the light left over from the very earliest moments of the universe, and from the advent of gravitational wave observatories, like the NSF's LIGO, which have provided an entirely new means of looking at the world. In fact, neutrinos and their interactions with other particles and with atomic nuclei can play an important, even dominant, role in both the early universe and in some of the violent events LIGO detects, like the collision and merging of neutron stars. How can this be if neutrinos have such weak interactions with matter? The answer is that the neutrinos can make up for their feeble interactions with huge numbers in these cosmic venues.

This is where the research accomplished under NSF funding comes in. A key objective of the research conducted under this NSF Award was the calculation of how neutrino properties, both those measured and those speculated on, influence the physics of the very early universe and its relic cosmic light, and influence the physics of the collapsing/collapsed stars that constitute the key players in, for example, the LIGO events. To accomplish this, the PI and his graduate students and postdocs and collaborators had to calculate how neutrinos interact with other particles and, especially, with atomic nuclei in these cosmic venues. And these are exotic environments, with ultra high temperatures and high densities. The atomic nuclei in these sites may not be like anything we can study in terrestrial labs. Likewise, these extreme conditions provide us with a new and unique "laboratory" for studying the possible properties and behaviors of neutrinos, and other elementary particles as well. 

What could we eventually learn from these investigations and how will that be useful? One issue that we address directly is the origin of both the lightest nuclei, like helium and deuterium, and the heaviest nuclei, like gold or uranium. This issue is, in turn, important in understanding how our universe got to be the way it is now. Our work also allowed us to study the fundamental properties of neutrinos and to vet potential extensions of our standard picture for elementary particle physics. This may be important in understanding other grand mysteries, for example the nature of the dark matter that makes up some quarter of all the stuff in the universe (by contrast, ordinary atoms constitute only some 4%).

Insight into these mysteries are fascinating, perhaps firing the imaginations and ambitions of young people for STEM fields. Moreover, the discoveries made in this research may drive breakthroughs in other areas of science. But in the end, one could ask about immediate, practical benefits of this research to, for example, health or technology or national security. As in many areas of basic science, this may be hard to discern at the current time. We can at least point to two accomplishments of the research funded under this Award. First, we developed techniques for using (calculating with) quantum mechanics to study extreme environments. Second, this research allowed the training of a number of PhD nuclear physicists. Training the next generation of scientists is clearly beneficial to this country.
